I have used the article to support the contention that the complications that will arise from speed and the heavy traffic that we are encountering and will encounter in increasing quantity call for a dedicated quarantine service backed by Commonwealth legislation and complementary State legislation. No quarantine precautions can ever vide full guarantee against, the introduction of exotic diseases. The question of human into. error arises. Virus carrying insects have been discovered as high as 20,000 feet no quarantine measure can combat that. The question of migratory birds arises, but this is not mentioned often. We have a common frontier between Papua and New Guinea and West New Guinea, or Irian Barat as it is now known. Australia has a long coastline. All these factors make valid my statement that there can be no guarantee. We must constandy keep our eradication machinery up to date. I support the conbave tention of the honourable member for Dawson that we must pay particular attenus tion to complete incineration methods at our airports and seaports. I advocate the setting up of maximum security laboratories. The House should constantly keep in mind the need to maintain our precontravenes cautions and to amend legislation as the need arises. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. In Committee The Bill.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Title: DEFENCE
text: Dawson) [10.1]- I refer to the Schedule, which reads in part: Section 67(1.) Omit 'Five hundred pounds', Insert Two thousand dollars or imprisonment five years'. I move: Omit-'Omi t "Five hundred pounds", insert "Two thousand dollars or imprisonment for five years".', Insert 'Omit "Five hundred pounds", insert "Punishable upon conviction by a fine not exceeding One hundred thousand dollars or imprisonment for a period not exceeding ten years".'. J listened with interest to the honourable members for Evans (Dr Mackay) and Calare (Mr England). I do not disagree with any of the points they made. But they do not agree with me on the seriousness of this matter and the need for the fine to be increased. The honourable member for Evans did not interpret sections 67 (1.) as I do, and the honourable member for Calare thinks that imprisonment for 5 years is sufficient. Section 67 (1.) is one of the most frightening provisions that could be profound in any legislation. It reads: No person shall knowingly import, or bring . . . Australia, any noxious insect, or any pest, or any disease germ and 'Knowingly' means that the person knows about it. He has full knowledge of the facts and he knows that he brings into Australia a dreaded animal, human or plant disease.

Speaker: Dr FORBES
Title: DEFENCE
text: No .

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Title: DEFENCE
text: That is the way the section could be interpreted. It is all very well for the Minister for Health to say that the section does not mean that. We had our legal people look at it and we are told that it could mean that. Let take the case of a leper or somebody who knows that he has a disease, wants tn come into Australia and smuggles himself into the country in one way or another. He section 67(1.) of the Act. A person who clips or defaces a 20c piece can be imprisoned for up to 10 years. Which offence is the more serious, the deliberate introduction of an exotic human, animal or plant disease or the clipping of a 20c piece? The cattle people and the representatives of the organisations to whom I have spoken in the last 3 months think that the penalty now provided is completely inadequate. The question might be asked: What sort of person would deliberately introduce such a disease into Australia? I think that very few people would do so and frankly for I find it difficult to give an example of such an act being done. But let us not forget that a lot of cranks play around with these things. History has shown that some of the most serious plant diseases, animal diseases and parasites have been deliberately introduced into this country. I do not say that a person would deliberately introduce prickly pear if he were aware of the serious consequences. Harrisia cactus would not have been introduced if the consequences had been known. A person would not deliberately introduce an exotic animal disease if he knew the consequences. But the amendment is intended to introduce a penalty that will serve as a warning to people in other countries. It is a warning to anybody who thinks of bringing into Australia animals or plants that could be infected. As 1 said before, there are plenty of cranks who might knowingly and deliberately bring a disease into Australia. How do we know what is lurking in the future? The introduction of these exotic diseases could cripple Australia. This may be fantastic thinking, but it would be possible for a high flying aeroplane to ba sent across the north of Australia loaded with the viruses of animal, plant or human diseases. Jf they were dropped into Australia they would wreck our economy. It might be argued that only the cranks or the enemies of Australia would do that. But the point 1 make is that somewhere in our legislation we should have a provision that will warn people that if they set out on this sort of caper they will face a penalty of $100,000 or imprisonment for 10 years and not merely a fine of $2,000 or imprisonment for 5 years. Knowingly or deliberately to introduce a serious exotic disease, whether it be plant, animal or human, is virtually an act of treason. It is all very well for the Minister to say that my interpretation of the provision is not right. We have had our legal advisers look at the provision and we are told that it could be interpreted in the way that I have suggested. The world 'knowingly' means 'knowing', lt does not have two meanings. A person who knowingly does something knows that he is doing it. If he knowingly imports a disease germ he knows that he is doing so. It is not an accident. The Act provides for people who accidently bring diseases into Australia. If a migrant came in with the virus of foot and mouth disease on his shoes, he would not be subject to the provisions of section 67(1.). That is clearly an accident. The provision is designed to deal with a person who deliberately gets around the quarantine laws and brings in a disease that could result in a tragedy for Australia.

Speaker: Dr FORBES
Title: DEFENCE
text: Barker-Minister for Health) [10.8]-The Government opposes the amendment. In imposing the general and material increases in penalties the Government was keenly aware, and was just as aware as the honourable member for Dawson (Dr Patterson) is, that section 67 (1.) is the cornerstone of our quarantine edifice. It is recognised that the person who knowingly breaches the quarantine laws, whatever his motives, can introduce a threat to the health of the people of this country and a threat to our primary industries which might in the event assume the gravest of proportions. For this reason section 67 (1.) is amended by the Bill so that it will carry the heaviest penalty of all, and that is a fine of $2,000 or imprisonment for 5 years. It is argued that this penalty would not even remotely approach the value of the damage that could be caused. One of the more severe exotic diseases, animal or plant, could be introduced. But even the penalty proposed by the Opposition would pale into insignificance when compared with the possible national cost of such a disease. The costs have been mentioned by the honourable member for Dawson and by my colleagues on this side of the chamber. The Government has adopted other and, I believe, more realistic criteria in fixing the level of penalties. These criteria are firstly the general penalty structure under the present Act and under the Bill and secondly, the penalties provided by the Parliament under legislation comparable with the Quarantine Act. We just cannot pick a particular piece of legislation out of the air and say that we are going to impose penalties quite independently of everything we do in relation to penalties in the whole framework and structure of Commonwealth legislation. We must have regard to certain principles and broad comparability with respect to it. The third criteria that the Government had regard to were the actual penalties which the courts have imposed for breaches of section 67(1.). With respect to the first of these, as I mentioned earlier, this provision carries under the Bill the severest penalty whilst under the Act it carried the severest monetary penalty. But it did not carry, as some of my colleagues on this side of the House mentioned, the alternative of a prison sentence, although some other sections did provide goal penalties. To that extent the penalty proposed is relatively more severe than it is under the Act. With respect to the comparability of penalties provided by this Act, all I can say is that the Government has examined very carefully the penalties suggested in the Bill. Bridges-MaxweU, C. W. With respect to the third criterion, there have been very few prosecutions under section 67 (1.) and over the last decade the heaviest penalty imposed by a court bas been $100, even though, of course, the maximum penalty up to now has been $1,000. However, I should make the point that the normal procedure is to take action under the Customs Act. In most cases offenders choose to be dealt with by the Minister for Customs and Excise instead of by a court. Penalties imposed are of the order of $10 to $20. A notable exception was a case in 1965, which was mentioned by the honourable member for Dawson when a court imposed a penalty of $500 for the illegal importation of bull semen into Queensland. The penalties imposed by courts are generally fixed having regard to the seriousness which the courts attach to the offences and are not necessarily to be related to the maximum penalty provided by the legislation. The history of breaches of section 67 (1.) therefore does not suggest a maximum penalty even remotely approaching that proposed by the Opposition. The decision as to what is a suitable maximum penalty to be provided in legislation is, of course, one which cannot be resolved with precision by some magic formula. However, in the context of Commonwealth legislation generally and of other penalties under the Quarantine Act, the penalty proposed is a reasonable one and was decided on by the Government after considering the criteria to which I have referred. On those grounds the Government must oppose the amendment moved by the honourable member for adopted. Dawson. Question put: That the words proposed to be omitted (Dr Patterson's amendment) stand part of the Bill. The Committee divided.  Ayes . . .. . . 68 Noes . . .. . . 37 Majority 31 NA Adermann, C. F. Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: PAIRS
text: the Attorney-General, upon notice: What progress has been made since his answer to me on: (a) 19th May 1967 (Hansard, page 2474) towards introducing the new Acts Interpretation Act, the new Cheques Act and the uniform criminal code for the Territories, (b) 1st November 1967 (Hansard, page 2608) towards introducing legislation required to enable Australia to become a party to the Neighbouring Rights Convention of 1961, and (c) 25th October 1967 (Hansard, page 2220) towards introducing legislation to permit soldiers to make wills at 18 years? Mr Bowen- I now provide the following answer to the honourable member's scholarships question: (a) Further progress towards the introduction of a new Acts Interpretation Act has not as yet been possible because of the attention required be given to other more urgent projects. With year? regard to a new Cheques Act discussions with interested bodies bave been completed and instructions for the final draft nearly completed. With regard to the uniform criminal code for the Territories a meeting of Committee of the Law Council of Australia allowances working on the preparation of the draft uniform criminal code was held in Melbourne in the last week of January lofinalisethe draft. I understand the draft will be considered at the Executive of the Law Council to be held late in March and if approved will be then presented to Commonwealth. (b) As a result of my consideration of possible legislation to enable Australia to become a party to the Convention, the rights which the Convention requires to be conferred on record manufacturers and broadcasting organisations were included in Copyright Bill which I presented and which is now the Copyright Act 1968. It is proposed to bring this Act into force on 1st May 1969. I have written to interested organisations seeking their views on other provisions Convention and am giving thought to the replies (a) amount and (b)studies I have received. (c) Since my answer of 25th October 1967 the whole approach to legal rights of persons who attain the age of 18 years has been under review in Australia. The question of power to make wills is being attended to in general legislation. Some of the States have legislated to NA upon notice were circulated: who attain 18 years to make a will. Similar provision has been made by the Wills Ordinance 1968 of the Australian Capital Territory. Legislation will shortly be introduced in the Northern Territory Legislative Council. Post-Graduate Scholarships and Fees (Question No. 745)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE

The information requested is set out in a table which follows. The Commonwealth, in brief, is contributing a total sum of $9m to university research in the triennium 1967-69 compared with a total of $5m in the previous 1969 triennium. Enrolments In examining the figures in the table it should 1968 Increase % be remembered that in 1966 the Universities increase Commission merely recommended $10m for research in the universities. It made no division between the Special Research Grants and the 413 20.7 funds to be allocated by the Australian Research 402 27.8 Grants Committee. It also needs to be 58 21.2 remembered that in the triennium 1964-66 the 24 15.7 States and the Commonwealth both shared equally 27 13.6 on a dollar for dollar basis the support of these 135 11.3 funds. A total of $6m was made available for 288 26.9 Special Research Grants and $4m through the 49 92.5 Australian Research Grants Committee. 207 28.7 The decision which the Government made in 70 8.6 1966, after considering the Third Report of the 20 21.1 Australian Universities Commission, was to pro84 16.7 vide half of a total sum of $6m for the purpose 48 31.8 of general research in the State universities on condition that the States provided the other half, 65 11.0 and to provide half of a further sum of Slim for distribution through the Australian Research Grants Committee on condition that the States provided the other half. At the time of announcing the Commonwealth's decision (21st September 1966), we did not know whether all States would provide their half of the Slim for distribution through the Australian Research Grants Committee. We therefore went on to say that, although we were prepared to provide half of the money required for a research programme totalling $17m over the triennium, we could not provide, from our own resources, more than $9m over the triennium and, because of the importance which we attach to the Australian Research Grants Committee, we regarded that Committee as having first call on our available funds. We therefore said that to the extent that any State did not support the grant to the Australian Research Grants Committee, we would be compelled to reduce our contribution to the special research grant and that it was for each State to decide what it would do in the matter. In the event, four States, Queensland, Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia, decided to meet the whole of the special research grant for their universities and none of the grant to the Australian Research Grants Committee. Neither the New South Wales nor the Victorian Government has been prepared to accept any financial participation in the Australian Research Grants Committee expenditure, nor have they been prepared to meet in full the special research grant their universities. The Commonwealth is therefore meeting the whole of the grant of $9m for the Australian Research Grants Committee and no State contributes to it. Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: the Minister for Education and Science, upon notice: 1. On what occasions and with what results has the Government considered the development or establishment of a tropical marine biological research station since Senator Gorton's answer to Senator Murphy on 19th May 1964 (Hansard page 1227)? 2. What submissions have been made to or by the Australian Universities Commission concerning a grant for such a station at the Townsville University College since the Commission's third report was submitted on 29th August 1966?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1. The Government has been approached on a number of occasions by the Great Barrier Reef CommiUee for direct financial assistance for the development of facilities at the research station on Heron Island on the south section of the Great Barrier Reef. The Government has refused these requests on the ground that it already supports research on Heron Island through grants to the University of Queensland on the recommendations of the Australian Universities Commission and the Australian Research Grants Committee. The Commonwealth is giving support to the development of tropical marine biological research in a number of ways. Since 1964 the following grants, shared equally between the Commonwealth and the Queensland Governments have been for allocated under the Australian Universities Commission program to the Heron Island Research Station: 1964-66-$20,00 0 1967-69-$30,00 0 On the recommendation of the Australian Reduction Research Grants CommiUee the Commonwealth Government has awarded grants totalling $25,420 for projects concerning aspects of tropical marine Amount Per- biology for the 1967-69 triennium. The Commoncentage wealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has since 1964 also been associated with tropical marine biological research. It has partici$'000 % pated with the Queensland Government and the 70 Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry 70 in a survey of prawn resources in the south 70 eastern corner of the Gulf of Carpentaria. Grants 98 70 totalling $1,152 were made in 1967 and 1968 from 42 70 the Science and Industry Research Fund for bio56 logical studies on the Great Barrier Reef. 70 70 2. The University College of Townsville has 40 recently placed before the Australian Universities 48 40 Commission a formal request for the establish40 ment of a centre for research in tropical marine 48 40 science during the triennium 1970-72. The pro40 posed centre would be concerned with both 40 physical and biological sciences. The Commission 40 is now considering the proposal and will in due course make recommendations. Queensland Power Resources Station (Question No. 796) Dr Everingham asked the Minister for National Development, upon notice: 1. Has his attention been drawn to reported statements on 1st August 1968 of the Director of Industrial Development for Queensland, Sir David Muir, that central Queensland coal deposits are one of the potentially cheapest power sources in the world, but this could not be competitive on a world basis without a power house investment of JlOOm to $200m which should be found urgently at State and Federal level in the vital interests of Australia? 2. Is there evidence to support Sir David's reported statement that lack of cheap power will retard growth in primary production, has prevented the setting up of aluminium refining in Central Queensland, and will retard the expanding salt and sulphuric industries there, including a large-scale alkali plant which is needed so that central Queensland salt would no longer have to be shipped to New South Wales as at present to make caustic soda for the Gladstone alumina refinery? 3. Is he able to say whether the Queensland Treasurer recently failed in an overseas mission to attract foreign capital for the purposes of providing this cheap power for Queensland? , 4. Is it a fact that Queensland provides many times its share of .earnings towards a favourable balance of Australia's trade? S. Has there been disinterest and delay in his Department' in connection with the prolonged, urgent, sane and business-like proposal of Queensland for remunerative Commonwealth investment in (his unquestionably warranted giant power house project; if so, wilt he investigate this matter and provide an explanation at an early date? Mr Fairbairn-The following answer is now supplied: 1. The Premier of Queensland has submitted a case to the Commonwealth in connection with a major power station in central Queensland. 2. It is well known that the unit cost of power strongly affects the location of major power using industries sucb as the aluminium smelting and chemical industries which require low unit cost power to be viable. The provision of power at a sufficiently low unit cost to make such industries economic would require the construction of a upon notice: large scale power station involving a very substantial capital outlay. An assured demand for power would be required before the construction of major power station could be justified. 3. No. I an) not aware of the outcome overseas mission by the Queensland Treasurer. 4. Trade statistics for the 5 years to 1967-68 indicate that the ratio of exports to imports for Queensland averaged 2.48 : 1. The comparable answer: figure for Australia as a whole was 0.98 : 1. 5. There has been no disinterest and delay my Department. Racial Discrimination (Question No. 811) Dr Everingham asked the Attorney General, upon notice: 1. Has his attention been drawn to a report that the Netherlands Parliament is considering a Bill to prohibit public insult of, or incitement to hatred and discrimination against, any person or group because of their race, religion, or outlook on Jife? 2. As this is an essential principle in establishing a peaceful world order, will he study the Netherlands Bill with a view to the introduction of similar legislation here? Mr Bowen-The following answer is now supplied: 1. Yes. 2. The study presently being made of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination includes a consideration of legislation proposed or passed by other countries on the subject of racial discrimination. Constitutional Review Committee (Question No. 813)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: the Prime Minister, upon notice: 1. Has the Government given consideration to any of the recommendations of the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review since, his predecessor's answer to me on 17th October 1967 (Hansard page 1919)? 2. If so, to which recommendations has it given consideration? Mr Gorton-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The recommendations of the Joint Committee on Constitutional Review have been and are considered from time to time by the Government as part of the continuing process of law revision. As far as any particular recommendation is concerned, I have nothing to add to my predecessor's reply of 17th October 1967. Marriage of Minors (Question No. 823)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS UPON NOTICE
text: the Minister for 861 Defence upon notice: 1. Have the regulations of the various Services been amended since his answer to me on 29th August 1967 (Hansard, page 571), to give servicemen dishonourably discharged after 15 years service the same rights as public, servants to payment in lieu of furlough? 2. If so, when were the amendments made? Mr Fairhall-The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows: The Departments of the Navy and the Army have advised that advice received since my answer of 29th August 1967, (Hansard, page 571) indicates that no amendment of existing regulations is required to permit payments in lieu of furlough being made to members of tbose Services who have been dishonourably discharged after not less than 15 years service. The Air Force Regulations do however require amendment and the necessary instructions which are included in a complete review of the regulations relating to furlough will be issued shortly. Strikes and Lockouts (Question No. 923) Mr Clyde Cameron asked the Minister Labour and National Service, upon notice: 1. On what occasions since 1904'has the Commonwealth Arbitration Court penalised (a) a trade union or employee for supporting or being involved in strike action, and (b) an employers organisation or employer for supporting or being involved in a lockout? 2. What was the (a) penalty and/or cost imposed and (b) the date of the conviction, in each case? Mr Bury-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: 1. and 2. The honourable member will know that in 1930 the provisions of what was then the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904-1928 relating to strikes and lockouts were repealed. The only records available in a readily accessible form regarding penalties imposed on parties relate to proceedings taken during and since 1952 under the present sections 109 (1.) (a) and (b) and 111 (and the former sections 29 (t>) and (c) and 29A) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. These sections do not contain provisions for penalising a trade union or an employee for supporting or being involved in strike action or for penalising an employers organisation or an employer for supporting or being involved in a lockout. The provisions of paragraphs (a) and (b) of sub-section (1.) of Section 109 of the Act empower the Commonwealth Industrial Court to order compliance with an award proved to the satisfaction of the Court to have been broken or not observed, and to enjoin an organisation or person from committing or continuing a contravention of the Act or Class of ship or aircraft ShipsDDG Destroyer (HMAS. July 1963 'Brisbane') Oberon Class Submarines (4) February 1963 Minesweepers-Inshor e (3) May 1966 to AircraftHelicopters-Iroquoi s (7) . . March 1963 to Skyhawk A4G and TA4G January 1966 . . (10) Tracker S2E (14) April 1965 AircraftHelicopter-Siou x (52) July 1962 Pilatus Porter (14) May 1967 a breach or non-observance of an award. Section 111 empowers the Court to impose a penalty in respect of a contempt of the Court consisting of a failure to comply with an order of the Court made under paragraph (a) or (b) of sub-section (1.) of section 109. The former sections 29 and 29A of the Act gave similar powers to the Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration. If the honourable member so desires I will provide him, at his request, with such information as is readily available relating to applications under section 109 (or the former section 29) and contempt proceedings under section 111 (or the former section 29A) in respect of the period 1952 to 1968. Information about costs, however, is not readily available. Defence: Ship and A i r c r a ft Purchases Overseas (Question No. 929)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ARMY
text: the Minister for Defence, upon notice: What is the basis of relativity between male and female rates of pay in the Services? Mr Fairhall-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Servicewomen receive in group pay an element (formerly called a margin) equal to that of males where the duties are identical. Their basic pay component bears the same relationship to that of males as exists in the Commonwealth Public Service. Rank pay for servicewomen is two-thirds that of rank pay for men because of the lower rank responsibilities of female members of the Services. (Question No. 943) Br Everingham asked the Minister for National Development, upon notice: As the Bureau of Mineral Resources is spending S2.7m this financial year searching for oil, will he consider equipping it to take over much of the oil search at present undertaken by overseas private investors with Government subsidy, or alternatively seek Government equity in all oil found with Government subsidy? The Government is actively considering all other aspects of its future participation in Ihe search for oil. Vietnam: Australian Broadcasting Commission News Broadcast (Question No. 944) Dr Everingham asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice: 1. Has his attention been drawn to an Australian Broadcasting Commission evening news broadcast of 28th September which reported 33 Vietcong killed and 20 injured when a Royal Australian Air Force Canberra jet dropped four Oil Search 500 lb bombs from 15,000 feet at night? 2. If so, will he confirm or deny this report? 3. Can he disclose the source of this information? If not, why not? 4. Will he investigate the reliability of reports of casualties? Mr Fairhall-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: l . Yes. 2, 3 and 4. The report of the operation and casualties resulted from an official news release made by the Department of Air on 28th September 1968. The information for the news release was provided by Headquarters, Australian Force Vietnam. Divorce Laws (Question No. 960)

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ARMY
text: the Attorney-General, upon notice: 1. Has his attention been drawn to a report in in which a Victorian supreme court judge described Australia's divorce laws as inadequate and, not infrequently, being the cause of injustice? 2: Is the time ripe, as suggested by the eminentjudge, for a 'new look' tribunal, including a psychiatrist, social worker, lawyer and accountant, to deal with divorce and matrimonial - causes in° Australia? Mr Bowen- I now provide the following answers to the honourable member's questions: My attention has been drawn to a newspaper report concerning certain proposals made recently, by Mr Justice Barber of the Supreme Court of Victoria. The proposals were contained in a paper presented by His Honour at a recent symposium on family law reform at Monash University. In the paper the Judge proposed a new family law code, the Commonwealth enacting a new marriage and divorce code, with uniform State legislation in the fields in which the Commonwealth has no powers, such as testators family maintenance. He also proposed the establishment of a 'family court', with jurisdiction to deal with matrimonial causes, custody, access and welfare of children, maintenance and property settlements." The Judge's proposals are being studied, along wilh views of other persons and bodies that have advocated changes in the field of family law. Whether the law should be amended is a matter of policy. (Question No. 961)

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ARMY
text: the Minister-in-charge of Aboriginal Affairs upon notice: 1. What is the Aboriginal population, comprising full bloods and part bloods, as a percentage of the total population of Australia? 2. Of the full blood and part blood Aboriginal population, how many (a) have graduated from a university in the last 10 years, (b) are practising lawyers, (c) are practising doctors, (d) are employed as academics in a teaching or research position in an Australian University of technical college, (e) are members of a State or Federal Parliament, (f) are qualified secondary teachers and (g) are qualified primary teachers?

Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Title: ARMY
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: The Commonwealth Statistician has advised that: (i) Due to the imprecise reporting at the 1966 census of persons of Aboriginal descent it is not possible to make a reliable separate distinction of persons of varying degrees of Aboriginal blood. The statistics available from the census therefore relate to all persons who reported that they were of Aboriginal descent to the extent of one-half or more. The total number so reported at the 1966 census was 80,207 persons of 0.69% of the Australian population. (ii) For census purposes persons are classified to the occupations in' which they were working at the time of Ihe census. An analysis of statistics so obtained shows that of the 80,207 persons mentioned above: . (a) Three males had reported that they had a university degree, but the date at which the degree was obtained was not sought at the census. (b) None were classified as lawyers. (c) One male was classified a medical practitioner. (d) None were classified as university teachers. (e) None were classified as members of a State or Federal Parliament. (f) 15 males and 30 females were classified as teachers, some of whom may have been trainee teachers. In view of the difficulties encountered at the census with the reporting of race and the very small numbers involved in particular occupations, the figures should not be considered to be precise measurements of the categories concerned. Tariff Board (Question No. 966)

Speaker: Mr HAYDEN
Title: ARMY
text: the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice: Aboriginals 1. What special powers are provided for the Minister under sub-paragraphs (i) and (iii) of section 15 (1) (h) of the Tariff Board Act? 2. Has he made any reference to the Tariff Board under these provisions; if not, why not? 3. If references have been made, what are the details of the (a) above references, (b) reports from the Board and (c) the dates of the references and reports? Mr MCEwen-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as foUows: 1. Section 15 (1) (h) of the Tariff Board Act 1921-1966, provides that the Minister shall refer to the Board for inquiry and report the following matters: (h) any question whether a manufacturer is taking undue advantage of the protection afforded him by the Tariff or by the restriction of the importation of any goods, and in particular in regard to his(0 charging unnecessarily high prices for his goods; or (ii) acting in restraint of trade to detriment of the public; or (iii) acting in a manner which results in unnecessarily high prices being charged to the consumer for his goods, and shall not take any action in respect of any of those matters until he has received the report of the Board. 2. Yes. 3. Since I have been responsible for these matters, it has been my normal practice to all references to the Board under the authority section IS as a whole. The Board has thus been empowered to investigate and report on all aspects of the cases referred to it including any instance of undue advantage being taken of the Tariff. In November 1967, I sent to the Board a reference worded specifically in terms of section IS (1) (h). The reference covered local manufaceffectiveness ture of case board and panelboard. The Board's report has not yet been received.

Speaker: Mr STEWART
Title: ARMY
text: the Minister for National Development, upon notice: 1. Have any investigations been made by his Department into modem methods offightingbush fires? 2. If so, what have these investigations disclosed, and has the information been passed on to State governments? 3. Is he able to say whether any other countries have more efiicient methods offightingbush fires? 4. If so, what are these methods, and is it possible to introduce them to Australia? 5. Do any other countries use specially equipped aircraft to fight bushfiresand is this method considered efficient? 6. If so, are there any aircraft in Australia, for example, Neptune bombers, which would be suitable, after transformation, to perform this task? Mr Fairbairn-The following answer is now supplied: I . The Fire Control Research Section of the Forestry and Timber Bureau of my Department has been actively engaged on the development of and investigation into more effective methods of bushfire suppression and control since 1954. This programme of bush fire research has covered both forest fire fighting methods and grassland problems. The programme has involved intensive experiments into the fire behaviour aspects of these two major fuel types and during this period some 1200 experimental fires have been burnt and studied in detail. In conjunction with this experimental programme a large proportion of the major forest and grassland fires which have occurred in Australia over the past fifteen years have been thoroughly investigated in the field. The Officer-in-charge of this Section has also visited Canada and the United States on two occasions in the past four years and in association with State fire control officers bas kept in close touch with developments in fire fighting methods including the use of water bombing aircraft and helicopters in both these countries. The effectiveness of North American practice in relation to the specific requirements and problems of the Australian environment is being constantly evaluated. The Fire Research Section has kept in close touch with the more effective equipment developsend ments and maintains a fire tanker and crew of which frequently combines with fire fighting activities in the Australian Capital Territory and adjoining areas of New South Wales in order to test and evaluate any new pieces of equipment and more efficiently evaluate existing methods used by the volunteer fire fighting organisations. Work has also been carried out on the use and of various chemical fire rerardants from both aircraft and ground tanker applications. Currently the Section is co-operating with the Forests Commission of Victoria on an evaluation of Snow Commander, Beaver and Piper Pawnee Bush Fires aircraft in a fire suppression system. (Question No. 967) 2. (a) A major result of the Department's bushfire research has been the evolution of successful methods of control burning. By this means the often very heavy accumulation of dry' fuel on the ground in forest country (in the form of forest litter, dry grass, and deadwood) can be safely reduced by burning off in cool calm weather and before the fuel has dried out completely after rain. This is a skilled operation requiring detailed assessment of weather conditions, and of the weight and degree of dryness of the fuel, but has been proved to be a very effective method of reducing the severity of wildfiresoccurring in hot, dry and windy weather, so that thesefirescan be quickly suppressed or brought under control. The technique can be used effectively by ground crews in easy country, but a fairly recent development which is simpler and more effective in fiat or rolling country and which allows the technique to be extended to mountainous country where ground operations would be virtually impossible, is aerial control-burning. It was first evolved by the Forests Department of Western Australia and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and has now become standard practice in West Australian forest areas, but the Fire Control Research Section has been instrumental in evaluating, testing and improving the technique and successfully extending its use to mountainous forest areas in the eastern States. In aerial control-burning, incendiary devices are dropped from a light aircraft in a regular pattern over the area to be burnt Forest areas on the south coast of New South Wales which had recently been control-burnt by aerial methods proved remarkably effective during the serious fires which occurred on 28th October 1968. Once the fires entered the control-burnt forest, they were quickly controlled. On 1st August 1968, the Management Council of the Hume-Snowy Fire Control Organisation approved the incorporation of a programme of aerial control burning as an integral part of the fire control system in that region. (b) Information on the behaviour of all major forest and grassland fires and comments on the effectiveness of the suppression methods and suppression tactics used during the course of the fires has been supplied to the State Forest Services and rural fire authorities. The results of all bushfire research are also passed on to the Forest and Rural Fire authorities in each State, as soon as significant results are obtained. In addition, the Forestry and Timber Bureau arranges periodic conferences on forest fire control at which the results of research and improvements in operational practices are fully discussed. The last such conference was held in Perth during October in 1968. 3 and 4. Bushfire research carried out by my Department in various States has shown that fire behaviour in eucalypt forests is vastly different from that prevailing in North American or European forests largely due to the ability of eucalypt forests to throw burning embers long distances ahead of the main fire under strong wind conditions. This factor alone indicates that it requires different methods of fire fighting than are practiced in most other countries. In addition to this, fires in eucalypt forests burn much faster and build up to conflagration proportions much more rapidly than in forest types common to the northern hemisphere and this factor requires very fast and concentrated initial attack on fires as thcy occur. These two fire behaviour characteristics are the main reasons why water bombing aircraft methods, which are claimed to be more efficient, would be much less effective in this couniry. Canada and the United States are considered to have highly developed fire control organisations embodying the use of the very expensive system of water bombing aircraft. However, this system still fails under very severe drought conditions such as experienced in the north western United States last year when a number of very large fires burnt through high-value forest country. It can be fairly stated that there are no lire fighting methods or techniques developed in any couniry of the world which can control a forest fire which has reached conflagration proportions in heavy fuel quantities under severe meteorological conditions. Nevertheless, current research and operational practice indicates that medium sized water bombing aircraft will be effective in controlling or containing lightning fires which have occurred in remote forest country, and their use has already become operational practice by the Forests Commission of Victoria. 5. The United States, some provinces of Canada, and France use specially equipped aircraft to fight forest fires and in general their use produces reasonably effective results for the special environments in which they are used. However, in both the United States and Canada the use of water bombing aircraft against high intensity, fast moving fires seldom produces significant effect on the control of the fire perimeter. This ineffective use of aircraft results in very night costs and is the main reason why many fires in the 20,000 to 30,000 acres category have suppression costs exceeding $2m. 6. The Australian Forestry Council at its meeting at Mount Gambier in 1967 discussed reports by Australian experts who had been in Canada and the United Siates studying the technique of fire bombing in the light of an offer made to Australia for the purchase or lease of some Canadair CL-215 aircraft. It was decided by the Council, which consists of Commonwealth and State Ministers, that purchase of these aircraft should not be proceeded with. The aircraft are very expensive and there was some doubt as to whether they could operate satisfactorily in areas of Australia where we do not have the many unsnagged lakes and other stretches of water that are available in the United States and Canada. The Council, however, decided that light aircraft, such as crop dusters, may be suitable for use in fighting bush fires and recommended that a survey of existing light aircraft be undertaken to assess their suitability as water bombers. This study is now in course. It has been recently demonstrated that light aircraft, such as crop dusters, can be used successfully in the role of a water bomber and could be useful in containing fires caused by lightning in isolated and rugged country. This technique would be effective only if the fire is caught in the very early stages. The Council also considered the possibility of obtaining obsolete aircraft, particularly the Neptune P2V5 aircraft. The Royal Australian Air Force was approached to see whether it would be possible to obtain these aircraft but an assessment showed that they would probably be as expensive to modify and operate as the Canadair. In addition the Air Force indicated that it was fully committed and would not be able to operate or maintain the Neptunes. Defence: Ship and Aircraft Orders (Question No. 971)

Title: ARMY
text: the Attorney-General, upon notice: 1. How many persons sentenced by courts in monwealth, the Australian Capital Territory have undergone involving its(f) imprisonment in New South Wales in each of die laws made by last 20 years? 2. Is he able to say what costs have been incurred by New South Wales persons in prison in each of the last 20 years? 3. On what occasions and with what results have Commonwealth and State Ministers and answer: and officials consulted on the procedure and cost of keeping persons in State prisons? 4. What amount has the Commonwealth laws received in fines and costs imposed by courts the Australian Capital Territory in each of the last 20 years? Mr Bowen-The following answer is now reference supplied: 1. The information cannot be obtained from available records. 2. No. 3. The Premier of New South Wales raised the procedure, question of the cost of maintenance of Australian witnesses Capital Territory prisoners in a letter to the then Prime Minister dated 9th October 1967. On 5th question), January 1968 the Acting Prime Minister informed expect, however, that the Premier that the Commonwealth agreed in would attempt to formulate principle to the cost of maintenance of these uniform code of procedure, evidence prisoners being determined along lines consistent with arrangements between the Commonwealth and New South Wales with respect to children committed from the Australian Capital Territory to New South Wales institutions and the committal of persons suffering from mental disorders. On 14th February 1968 the Premier advised that was in accord with the suggestions and would have the matter examined with a view to subsequent discussions between officials. There have been a number of discussions between officials and a draft formula for calculating daily maintenance has been agreed between them subject to Treasury approval. I have written to the Treasurer seeking his views on the draft formula. 4. There is no separate accounting record these amounts. Judiciary Act: State Courts (Question Na 977)

Is it a fact that the Government has undergains taken to pay half the cost of measures entered into by the New South Wales State Government in the present drought in Eden Monaro, and has also stated that it is prepared to re-negotiate a different basis re-emerges in New South Wales on a large scale? 2. In my statement to the House on 26th ments, September I indicated that the Commonwealth tributed will meet half the Cost in thisfinancialyear relief measures which the New vernment may find it necessary to continue in the South Coast, Southern Tablelands and Cobar districts until the drought measures for which the Commonwealth has agreed to contribute are those which have been applied in New South Wales drought areas during the past three years. They include the provision of loans for carry on purposes where available through normal commercial channels; rebates of freight on the transport of fodder and water to drought affected areas and the transport of starving stock out of drought areas; expenditure to provide relief work for those unemployed in rural areas as a result of drought; and miscelAustralian laneous expenditure in relation to the drought, such as cloud seeding. In my statement of 26th September I also said that the Commonwealth would be prepared to consider new assistance arrangements if drought conditions were to re-emerge on a large scale. 2 and 3. A request was received from the Premier of New South Wales for Commonwealth assistance towardsfinancingof a subsidy on the purchase price of wlieat to feed stock in drought affected areas. I have advised the New South Wales Premier that my Government does not consider that the present circumstances call for the provision of special financial assistance of this kind to his State. Is he able to say whether the Australian Guarantee Corporation Ltd requires debenture accepted. holders to sign an indemnity without time limit when they apply for replacement or redemption of a lost debenture? 2. Is he able to say whether this practice to common with thia company as its shares are frequently alleged to be missing in the mail? 3. Mr Bowen-The following answer is now during supplied: 1. I am not able to say whether the Australian Guarantee Corporation Ltd has such a practice. 2. No. 3. I shall arrange for consideration to be given, in the course of the present review of the uniform Companies Act, to whether there is a need protection. Oflicer Period of absence and Mr A. R. Cumming Thom, 22.5.65 to 5.6.65 Department of the Malaysia and SingaSenate pore Vietnam (Question No. 1007) Total Mr Barnard asked the Minister for the Kingdom Army, upon notice: Can he give any information on the investigation 8 9 within his Department which he said, in reply to * the honourable member for Grayndler on 13th 25,126 August (Hansard, page 10), was proceeding into 27.585 a book on the Vietnam war by Major John Rowe? 30,819 43,375 Mr Lynch-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: As I said in my reply to the honourable member for Grayndler, at the time, my underof standing was that the book was a work of fiction. Subsequent examination of the matter has con1967-68 firmed this and the book has been accepted aa such. Even so, it should have been apparent to the author that the book, although written in fictional terms, was liable to misinterpretation and should have been submitted for clearance prior to the publication. He was informed to this effect in August and was subsequently advised that the matter could therefore be considered closed.. I should add that subsequently, on 21st 1968, Major John Rowe submitted an application to resign his commission go that he could concentrate on a writing career. Speaker: Mr CLYDE CAMERON
Title: CONCILIATION AND

How many rifle ranges for military use exist in Victoria? 2. Where are they located and what are their dimensions? 3. Is there any estimate, arrived at by Army authorities, as to the distance that a bullet fired on the Williamstown rifle range could travel when it overshoots the protective mounds by the Williamstown foreshore? 4. What are the locations and areas of Army rifle ranges in the vicinity of State capital cities other than Melbourne, and, in each instance, how far are these ranges from the heart of the city? Mr Lynch-The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1. There are four military ranges in Victoria. 2. Because of the difficulty in defining precisely what the term 'dimensions' means in regard to rifle ranges, I have supplied where practicable details of the areas of land they occupy. It should, however, be borne in mind that when a rifle range is part of a military range complex the actual area occupied by an individual range cannot always be stated precisely; for example, at Puckapunyal, which has a total Army land area of 53,000 acres: Bonegiiia-55 0 acres. Williamstown-30 0 acres (seaward firing). Puckapunyal-se e above. Portsea-locate d within Oflicer Cadet School training area of 1,318 acres. 3. The question does not specify what weapon and whatfiringpoint on the range are envisaged. However, the standard safety template distance behind target mounds on all classification ranges, of which Williamstown is one, is for at least 2,000 yards. This danger area is designed to accept all ricochets and also the occasional bullet in free flight which escapes just over the top of the stop butt. It is adequate for all types of small arms used. Experience has shown the 2,000 yards danger area to be satisfactory. At Williamstown the proclaimed danger area embraces the 2,000 yards referred to above. Rifle Ranges Area of No. of Range miles State/Territory (acres) from GPO QueenslandBelmont .. 1,251 9 Greenbank .. 11,474 25 New South WalesHolsworthy 500 18-20 (Green Hills) (approximately) Long Bay 357 8 (seaward firing) South Australia Port Adelaide 1,310 9 (Dean Range) Western AustraliaBushmead 733 12 Swanbourne .. 338 6 (Seaward firing) TasmaniaPontville .. 1,271 15 Australian Capital TerritoryMajura Located within 5.5 Royal Military CoUege field firing range of approximately 1,700 acres Arts Subsidy (Question No. 1035) Mr Duthie asked the Prime Minister, upon notice: 1. Is the bulk of the Government's subsidy in support of the arts to be allocated to those organisations which the Chairman of the Australian Council for the Arts founded and until recently, controlled, namely, the Elizabethan Theatre Trust, the Australian Ballet Company and the Drama Foundation? 2 Are the three professionals on the expert advisory panel allfinanciallybeholden to the executives of the organisations mentioned in question 1. 3. Did Dr Coombs choose this expert subcommittee? 4. What percentage of the total annual federal subsidy is to be allocated to theatre groups outside the Elizabethan Theatre Trust, the Australian Ballet Company and the Drama Foundation? Mr Gorton-The answers to the honour3. able member's questions are as follows: 1. The Australian Council for the Arts considers its primary responsibility is to subsidise the performing arts at a national level, and to be responsible for the establishment and maintenance of high national standards. It has,' therefore, given major subsidies this year to the Australian Opera, die Australian Ballet, the Marionette Theatre df Australia and the Elizabethan Theatre Trust Orchestra, all of which are the major companies in their field in Australia and all of which have an obligation to bring the arts to the widest possible audience within Australia. In addition, the Council has given the major grants in the case of drama to two companies, one in Melbourne and one in Sydney which will form tthe basis for. national level companies in the two. major centres of population, with obligations to tour in other States and to provide a .wide variety of services, the field of drama, including the production of new Australian plays. The Council is also, providing, assistance to comlic panies in the other State capitals healthy local growth, of drama is possible. In Commonwealth respect of other companies which operate within age support at all the confines of individual States or communities, community. In this the Council considers that the prime responsibility for their .support lies with State and local artistic matters. Splendid buildings governments. However, in " the interests of erected in many State capitals and considerable improving national standards the Council has established a large fund of money to support special projects devised and presented by these otber drama groups. The Council understands that companies which have been previously administered through the Elizabethan Theatre Trust will move in the near future towards autonomy. When this stage is reached the Council will deal directly with these companies on all matters affecting their work. Therefore, the Council has stipulated precise grants to be paid to these companies, even' where, for this year, the payments will be made through the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust: Details of grants for 1968-69 by the Australian Council for the Arts were announced by me on Uth December 1968. The text of my statement is included as an appendix to this answer. 2. I am informed that all the members of the Advisory Committee on Drama (other than members of the Council) have personal experience in one aspect or other of the theatre as producers, critics or teachers. Mr John Sumner is Director of the Melbourne Theatre Company (previously the Union Theatre Repertory Company) which has received financial assistance from the Elizabethan Theatte Trust, and Mr James Sharman is a freelance producer who has done work from time to time for drama and opera companies affiliated with the Trust. The other members are: Professor Macartney, Professor of Drama, University of Melbourne, Dr Thiersch, Lecturer of Modern Languages, University of Adelaide, Miss Patricia Rofe, Critic on 'Bulletin', Miss Katherine Brisbane, Critic on 'Australian'. The Committee was chosen by the Council of which Dr Coombs is Chairman. - 4. See answer to question 1. AUSTRALIAN COUNCIL FOR THE ARTS: GRANTS FOR 1968-69 Statement by the Prime Minister, Mr John Gorton I have received from the Chairman of the Australian Council for the Arts the Council's recommendations for grants to be made by the Commonwealth Government in support of the performing arts in the current financial year. This is the first year of the Council's existence and it has given considerable thought to the proper function for Commonwealth support for the arts in relation to other forms of support. The Commonin wealth contribution is only one among many. The arts belong to the whole community, and support for them should come from many sources-fro m State Governments, from local councils, from puborganisations and private individuals. It is to ensure that a therefore to be hoped that the lead given by the in sponsoring the arts will encourlevels throughout the Australian perceive a growing interestrespect it is heartening to by many States in are being help is being given to provide conditions in which the arts can flourish and Australians can take due pride in their increasing achievements in this field. The Council is of the opinion that its main concern as a Federal body should be to establish and develop high national standards which will benefit activity in the arts throughout Australia and stimulate interest abroad in Australia's cultural achievements. Its concern with quality is fundamental. To this end the Council has adopted a principle widely accepted by similar bodies in other countries, that high standards can best be achieved by a concentration of available funds rather than by a thin spread over a wide area. Much of the Council's work in these early stages is exploratory in nature. It has established working committees to seek expert opinion on its various areas of interest with a view to formulating in the near future tong range policies for Government support for the arts in Australia. The Government understands that a report will shortly be forthcoming from the Council on the work of its film committee which has begun inquiries into means by which film making for television may be supported. The Council has received requests for assistance in many categories other than the theatre arts to which its grants for this year have been restricted. It will begin inquiries as soon as possible into the need for assistance in some of these other fields and will advise the Government of its conclusions. In announcing the Council's recommendations for 1968-69 may I express the Government's pleasure at being associated with activities in the arts which contribute so significantly to the enrichment of Australia's national life and to her reputation in other countries. Water Conservation: Use of Nuclear Energy .. 14,000 (Question No. 1036) Mr Crean asked the Minister for National 5,000 Development, upon notice: 1. Has his attention been drawn to the advocacy by Professor T. D. J. Leech of the use of nuclear .. 15,000 blasts to help solve water conservation problems in Australia? 3,200 2. Is it a fact that major storages could be created by the use of nuclear devices? .. 15,000 3. Has any examination been made by oflicers of his Department of the effects of a considerable .. 12,000 number of nuclear devices that bave been fired in 4,000 Australia as air bursts? 4. Are the dangers of radiation a limiting factor in the application of such methods of storage 23,500 construction or can these dangers be suitably controUed? 5. When was a nuclear device last fired in Australia and how many such devices have.been fired? Mr Fairbairn-The following answer is now supplied: 1. Yes. 2. It would be theoretically possible to create water storages in a number of ways by detonation of nuclear explosives at shallow to intermediate depths below the ground surface. Such methods would include the formation of open craters, the .. 227,000 formation of 'chimneys' of broken rock below the ground surface, the creation of dams in gorges by artificially induced landslides and the accelerated re-charge of aquifers by breaking up the rocks . . 34,000 in the intake area. I should emphasise that, despite the undoubted promise of these methods, none has as yet been tested experimentally and proven effective for water storage. For a number of reasons, practical tests are essential. 3. No. Underground nuclear explosions give rise to significantly different effects from air bursts and, furthermore, the thermonuclear explosives which would be used to form water storages would create, quite.different radioactivity problems to the fission-type explosives detonated previously in Australia, lt is therefore not considered relevant to carry out a study of the type suggested. 4. The limiting factors in the use of nuclear explosions to create water storages would appear to be seismic shock and radioactivity. In fully contained explosions (i.e. those which do - not create a crater) there is virtually no release of radioactivity, but seismic shock damage may preclude projects in built up areas. Even in the case of cratermg explosions, the .seismic shock wave could be expected to be of the same order of importance as the release of radioactivity. Radioactivity release has been reduced markedly by design of special explosives for civil use. 5. Twelve nuclear devices have been exploded in Australia, the last on 9th October 1957. Decentralisation of Industry (Question No. 1038) Mr Charles Jones asked the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice: What legislation has been passed since 1964 to assist the decentralisation of industry? Mr MCEwen-The following answer is now provided: The question of location of industry has traditionally been a matter for State Governments and they have developed a variety of measures designed to attract industry to country areas. The Commonwealth's main role in furthering the decentralisation of industry has been to maintain a climate favourable to balanced development. A wide, range of legislative measures in the fields of transport mining and agriculture have contributed to this objective. The more substantial of those passed since 1964 are as follows: RailwaysRailway Agreement (Queensland) Act 1968 (supplementary assistance for CollinsvilleTowosvillc-Mt Isa Railway) Railway Agreement How many non-European migrants have been admitted annually to Australia for the past 10 years as permanent and long term arrivals and what were their nationalities? 2. What was their sex and occupation? Mr Snedden-Tb e answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows: 'Permanent and long term arrivals' is a statistical term for persons admitted for periods in excess of 12 months. The following figures relate only to persons admitted for indefinite stay or, in more recent years as migrants. They exclude persons admitted under temporary permit but with no intention of indefinite stay, even though the period of stay will exceed 12 months (e.g., staff of overseas compames, students and specialist workers). It was not until March 1966 when the Government reviewed the non-European policy that provision has existed for non-Europeans to be admitted as migrants. There has however been provision since the late 1950's for non-Europeans to be admitted under family sponsorship, for residence if the non-European is the spouse, dependent minor child, aged parent orfianceeof an Australian citizen or person having resident status in Australia. Until the second half of 1961 statistics were not maintained of the number of non-Europeans admitted during given periods. It is not possible therefore, to supply annual arrivals prior to 1st July 1961. From 1st July 1961 to 30th June 1968 the number of non-Europeans admitted for residence under family sponsorship and, since the March 1966 review of policy, as migrants has been: 1st July 1961 to 31 December 1961 .. 80 1962 1963 1964 1965 1966 1967 1st January 1968 to 30th June 1968 .. 810 Prior to the March 1966 review of policy, statistics were maintained under four broad nationality headings only. Judiciary Act: State Courts (Question No. 1057)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ASSISTED ARRIVALS BY SEA AND AIR
text: the Attorney-General, upon notice: On which of the matters on which the Compurchased monwealth Superior Court Bill permits Rules of Court to be made is the Judiciary Act committee empowered to recommend uniform rules to followed in State courts invested with federal iurisdiction? Mr Bowen-The following answer is now supplied: The Commonwealth Superior Court Bill permits Rules of Court to be made on matters of practice Or procedure and matters incidental to practice or procedure or necessary or convenient to be prescribed for the conduct of the Court's business. Some, but by no means all, of these matters are specifically mentioned in Uie Bill. As the Judiciary Act committee has been asked to report on the provisions of the Judiciary Act that at present require the application of State laws in Courts exercising federal jurisdiction in matters not Covered by the Constitution or the laws of the Commonwealth, it is empowered to recommend, if it is so inclined, uniform rules lo be followed in State courts, in matters of practice of procedure generally or in particular matters, when exercising federal jurisdiction. Hifar Reactor (Question No. 1059)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: ASSISTED ARRIVALS BY SEA AND AIR
text: the Minister for National Development, upon notice: 1. Is the Australian Atomic Energy Commission reactor HIFAR currently operating satisfactorily? 2. Is the Commission now satisfied with the safety of the reactor? 3. Why has the reactor not yet produced its full output of 15 MW as foreshadowed in the Commission's fifteenth report? Roads Mr Fairbairn-The following answer is now supplied: 1. Yes. 2. The Commission has never had any doubts concerning the safety of the reactor HIFAR. 3. As indicated in the fifteenth annual report, operation of HIFAR at 15 MW is dependent upon the introduction of Mark IV or V concentric type fuel elements. The United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority which is the sole manufacturer of this type of fuel element is as yet unable to provide a version which would be satisfactory for the conditions under which HIFAR is operated. Electron Microscopes (Question No. 1060)

Title: ASSISTED ARRIVALS BY SEA AND AIR
text: the Minister for National Development, upon notice: 1. What was the cost of the block of high activity handling cells to which reference is made on page 65 of the Fifteenth Annual Report of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission? 2. For what programmes, purposes and periods have cells been used? 3. Are the cells currently in use; if not, when were they last used? Mr Fairbairn-The following answer is now supplied: 1. $823,145. 2. and 3. The first block of high activity handling cells at the Australian Atomic Energy Commission Research Establishment were commissioned in 1960 next to the reactor HIFAR. These have been in continuous use since that date for the disassembly of irradiation rigs, the investigation of operating problems with HIFAR components and for the metallurgical examination and testing of irradiated materials being developed for fuel elements for future power reactors. The new block of high activity handling cells was constructed to allow this work to be carried out more efficiently and to permit the introduction of other operations such as the separation of speciflc radioisotopes for medical use and chemical studies involving highly radioactive materials. The new cells aTe currently in the final stages of commissioning and it is expected that they wiil be used for work with highly radioactive materials early in the new year. Commissioning of the cells vacancies has involved checks on the various safety and professionalhave functional aspects, the incorporation of additional Atomic Energy features found necessary as a consequence of such surveys, the remedying by the contractor of minor ment? constructional defects appearing within the maintenance period, the provision of specialised in-cell services and the installation of the specialised cell equipment. Title: OF STUDENTS IN FINAL YEAR OF SECONDARY
text: the Minister or Education and Science, upon notice: 1. What is (a) the entry standard required and (b) the length of course offered by each kindergarten teachers' college listed in his statement of 14th August 1968 and by any other such institution? 2. How many (a) government and (b) nongovernment pre-school centres are there in each State? 3. How many persons have qualified as preschool teachers in each State in each of the last 10 years? 4. What were the enrolments of (a) government and (b) non-government pre-school centres in each State in each of the last 10 years? 5. What percentage of eligible children in each State was enrolled for pre-school education in each of the last 10 years? 6. What was the ratio of qualified pre-school teachers to enrolled children in (a) government preschool centres, (b) non-government pre-school centres and (c) all pre-school centres in (i) each State, (ii) each Territory and (iii) the Commonwealth in each of the last 10 years? 7. What percentage of persons employed as preschool teachers in (a) government pre-school centres, (b) non-government pre-school centres and (c) all pre-school centres in (i) each State, (ii) each Territory and (iii) the Commonwealth consisted of qualified pre-school teachers in each of the last 10 years? 8. What percentage of the income of (a) government pre-school centres, (b) non-government preschool centres and (c) all pre-school centres in (i) each State, (ii) each Territory and (iii) the Commonwealth was derived from (A) the Commonwealth Government, (B) State governments, (C) fees and (D) other sources in each of the past 10 years? 9. What percentage of persons enrolled as trainee pre-school teachers in (a) each State (b) each Terriis set out in the following table: New Percentage New Percentage Total male of female of new students Total students Total students 6,245 73.0 2,315 27.0 8,560 4,104 66.6 2,054 33.4 6,158 2,210 62.1 1,350 37.9 3,560 1,633 68.6 748 31.4 2,381 1,044 67.1 511 32.9 1,555 422 63.1 247 36.9 669 856 74.2 298 25.8 1,154 16,514 68.7 7,523 31.3 24,037 1967-Par t I, Students and Degrees Conferred. tory and (c) the Commonwealth received bursaries Teachers in each of the past 10 years, and what was the value of the bursary in each case expressed as a percentage of the aUowance payable at the time to tf trainee primary or secondary teacher? 10. Which department is responsible for the supervision of pre-school education in each State and Territory? 11. What is the number of Aboriginal children of pre-school age in each State, and what (a) number and (b) percentage of such Aboriginal children in each State is enrolled for pre-school education?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: OF STUDENTS IN FINAL YEAR OF SECONDARY
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1. (a) The required entry standard for each institution, as stated by that institution, is as follows: (i) Kindergarten Teachers' Colleges Sydney- A pass in English and four other subjects at the New South Wales Higher School Certificate Examination. A matriculation qualication is preferred. Melbourne- A pass in English and four other subjects at the Victorian Leaving Certificate Examination together with at least a further year of approved study and/or experience. A full or partial completion of matriculation requirements is preferred. Brisbane- A pass in English and four other subjects at the Queensland Senior Examination. Adelaide- A pass in English and four other subjects at the South Australian Leaving Examination (Public Examination Board, Technical or Area). Perth-To have qualified for the Western Australian Leaving Certificate. A matriculation qualification is preferred. (ii) Otber Institutions Sydney Day Nursery Teachers' College- A pass in English and four other subjects at the New South Wales Higher School Certificate. A matriculation qualification is preferred. Hobart Teachers' College-To have completed a year of matriculation study. Full matriculation qualifications are preferred. (b) For each of the institutions in (a) the length of course offered is three years. 2. (a) In the States most government assistance in respect of pre-school education takes the form of grants to independent bodies which administer pre-school centres classified, for the purpose of this question, as 'non-government' centres. In addition, most mainland States themselves provide and administer pre-school facilities, often in hospitals, child welfare institutions and the like. These 'government' centres are few in number and their enrolments are not included in the statistics which I shall quote in reply to later parts of this question. In Tasmania, however, the major part of pre-school education is provided at 60 government centres. 2 (b) Non-government pre-school centres in the States may be divided into two groups: (i) 'affiliated' or 'subsidised' centres which receive subsidies from State governments through affiliating organisations such as the Kindergarten Union; (ii) 'unaffiliated' centres, most of which do not receive government financial assistance. Centres in group (i) provide a generally recognised pre-school education; of those in group (ii) a small number provide a similar programme to those in group (i), while many provide little more than child minding facilides. For group (ii) the numbers given are approximate only. It could only be obtained by examining the financial accounts of individual pre-school centres, as they differ widely in their sources of income and in the manner in which that income is received. 8. (ii) (a) (b) (c). In the Northern Territory, 100% of running costs of government pre-school centres for Aboriginal children is met by the Commonwealth Government. For non-government centres for Aboriginal children, total income is not made public. For community pre-school centres the entire costs of buildings and salaries are met by the Commonwealth Government; full details of other income are not readily available. Of the two non-government community pre-school centres, received substantial initial capital assistance and receives 66.6% of running costs from the Commonwealth Government, the other is entirely supported by a mining company. A third centre destroyed by fire in 1966, received a subsidy from the Government equal to the teacher's salary. In the Australian Capital Territory, actual income of government pre-school centres is provided AND 1968 entirely by voluntary contributions from parents; however, these funds are applied only to providing equipment for the centres and wages of cleaners. All other expenses including staff salaries are met Tas. directly by the Commonwealth Government. The non-government pre-school centre receives no direct governmental assistance. 30.2 8.
