(c) The percentage of pre-school teacher trainees receiving bursary or scholarship assistance throughout the Commonwealth was 31.8 in 1962, 29.4 in 1963 and 38.5 in 1968. 10. My information is that the following government departments are involved in varying degrees in the supervision of pre-schools: New South Wales: The New South Wales Department of Education through the Kindergarten Union of N.S.W., and the New South Wales Child Welfare Department through the Sydney Day Nursery and Nursery Schools Association. Victoria: The Victorian Health Department. Queensland: The Queensland Department of Education through the Creche and Kindergarten Association of Queensland. South Australia: The South Australian Education Department through the Kindergarten Union of South Australia. Western Australia: The Western Australian Education Department through the Kindergarten Association of Western Australia. Tasmania: The Tasmanian Education Department. Northern Territory: The Department of Education and Science and the Department of the Interior. Australian Capital Territory: The Department of Education and Science. 11. The number of Aboriginal children in preschool centres in each State is not known. Education: Reports to Commonwealth Government (Question No. 934)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: TRAINEES IN RECEIPT OF BURSARY OR
text: the Minister for nominated Education and Science, upon notice: 1. What persons and bodies have been called upon to report to the Commonwealth Government on educational matters since Sir Robert Menzies' answer to me on 5th May 1965 (Hansard, 1199)? 2. What was the purpose of their inquiries, a when were they called upon to initiate their inquiries, and when were their reports received?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: TRAINEES IN RECEIPT OF BURSARY OR
text: The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows: The honourable member's attention is directed to the answer the Minister for Health (representing my predecessor) gave him in reply to his Parliamentary Question No. 686 on this matter (Hansard 2 and 3 November 1967, page 2755). Since that reply was given, two further inquiries into educational matters have been instituted. On 2nd June 1968 I announced ment of a committee which, with the co-operation of the States, would inquire into and make mendations on the desirability conformity in the naming of awards for courses in Colleges of Advanced Education within the pendent broad approach that has so the development of the Colleges. The Committee, has fallen? Ifwhile which began its hearings in July, is being chaired by Mr F. M. Wiltshire, OBE., Managing Director of the Melbourne firm, The Wiltshire File Comgrants pany Pty Ltd. The other two members are ments and private? Professor J. J. Pratt, Professor of Education at the University of New South Wales and, with the agreement of the New South Wales Minister for Education, Dr R. L. Werner, Director of the New South Wales Institutes of Technology and follows: Business Studies. This Committee has not yet reported. On 6th June 1968 I announced in the House of Representatives that, after detailed discussions with the States, the Government had decided to establish an inquiry into academic salaries in leges of advanced education. (Hansard, page 2078). The terms of reference of the inquiry are as follows: To advise on salaries of lecturer and senior lecturer in colleges of advanced education having regard to present levels of academic and professional salaries in Australia, with a view to such advice being used by the Commonwealth Advisory Committee on Advanced Education as the basis for recommending grants for colleges of advanced education. The inquiry consists of a judicial figure who is assisted by two assessors, along the lines of the Inquiry into University salaries which was conducted by Mr Justice Eggleston in 1964. The Honourable Mr Justice C. A. Sweeney, a Deputy President of the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and a Presidential Member of the Trade Practices Tribunal, has as assessors Mr H. H. Dickinson, a member of the Public Service Board of New South Wales, and Mr D. R. Zeidler, Executive Director at the Imperial Chemical Industries of Australia and New Zealand Limited since 1962. These two assessors were by the States of New South Wales and Victoria respectively. This Committee has not yet reported. As was the practice on the two previous occasions this answer does not include the activities of bodies, such as the Commonwealth Advisory page Committee on Advanced Education and the Australian Universities Commission, which have continuing responsibility for advising the Minister. Education: Commomvealth Grants (Question No. 1014) Dr 3. F. Cairns asked the Minister for Education and Science, upon notice: 1. Are grants under the States Grants (Science Laboratories) Act made on the basis of the student population in both government and independent schools? If not, what criteria is used? 2. Did more independent schools than government schools receive Commonwealth aid in the the establishlast period? If so, why? 3. Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: TRAINEES IN RECEIPT OF BURSARY OR
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as 1. The distribution between groups of schools under the successive Acts providing grants for secondary school science facilities takes note of both State populations and secondary enrolment. Since 1st July 1967 the total annual amount for colindependent schools has been double what it was in previous years in accordance with the endorsement by the people at the 1966 election of the Government's proposal that this should be done. 2. No. More than 1,000 government schools and approximately 300 independent schools received assistance with laboratories or apparatus between 1st July 1964 and 30th June 1968. During that period the State authorities decided to make allocations for laboratories at 383 government schools and the State Advisory Committees for independent schools recommended initial grants for laboratories at 411 independent schools. 3. As the functions of the Commonwealth Advisory CommiUee on Standards for Science Facilities in Independent Secondary Schools relate only to independent schools, representative of the staffs of government schools are not included in its membership. 4. Yes, see 1 above. 3. Information on particular grants to individual independent schools and the names of government schools assisted with science laboratories covering the period 1st July 1964 to 30th June 1968 was included in Hsts which I circulated to honourable members on 27th March 1968 during the conDomestic rate1st Block 2nd Block Remainder Commercial rateIst Block 2nd Block 3rd Block Remainder General rate (manufacturing, industrial public institutions, etc.)1st Block 2nd Block 3rd Block 4th Block Remainder Street lighting rate Export Abattoir rate sideration of the States Grants (Science Laboratories) Bill 1968. The lists which I circulated in the House on 18th September 1968 gave details of assistance available in the three year period from 1st July 1968 to 30th June 1971 to those independent schools which bad been informed, as at 31st August 1968, of the grants allocated to them. Further lists will be made public from time to time. Australian Capital Territory and Northern Territory: Electricity Charges (Question 861)

Speaker: Mr HANSEN
Title: TRAINEES IN RECEIPT OF BURSARY OR
text: the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: 1. Is there only one entrance and exit to the Eagle Farm Airport at Brisbane? 2. Are there any emergency exits for use in the event of a blockage of the existing exit? 3. If not, can suitable exits be made across the General Water Pinkenba railway line? Rates $ s Mr SWARTZ - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1. Normally there is only one entrance road used by the travelling public to enter and leave the airport. 2. When races are held at Doomben an arrangement has been made with the Railways Department to provide airport access via the Schneider Road crossing. Other means of access can also be provided through Raceview Avenue and thence via the airport perimeter road or, alternatively, through the Bunour crossing along Reservoir Road. 3. Not applicable in view of the answer to Question 2. Northern Territory: Cultural Grants (Question No. 993)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: YWCA
text: the Minister for the Interior, upon notice: When will the Welfare Branch of the Northern Territory Administration complete its inquiry into youth organisations and the recreation needs of young people in the Territory? Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: The inquiry is a continuing one. A youth welfare officer has been appointed on a permanent basis to continue the inquiry and to provide practical assistance, leadership training and advice. As a result of surveys in the early stages of the inquiry four positions for youth activities and recreation officers for work with Aboriginals on missions and settlements have been created and it is hoped that these will be filled early in 1969. Northern Territory: Aboriginal Housing (Question No. 991)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: the Minister for the Interior, upon notice: 1. How many persons of Aboriginal descent were convicted in each of the last 5 years by courts in the Northern Territory? 2. What were the (a) principal offences involved and (b) number of convictions for each offence? 3. How many offenders were convicted more than once for the same offence, and what was the (a) offence, (b) number of convictions sentence in each case? Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourtory able member's questions is as follows: 1 to 3. No separate records are kept of offences by or convictions of persons Norlhern Territory: Interpreters for (Question No. 996)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: the Minister for the hospitals Interior, upon notice: 1. How many defendants of Aboriginal descent convicted in courts in the Northern Territory in each of the last 5 years were unable or only partially able to speak English? 2. In what (a) number and (b) percentages of these cases were interpreters provided by the court? Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: 1 and 2. No attempt is made to keep such years? records on a racial basis and the information sought is therefore not known. With a few exceptions the people of Aboriginal descent convicted by the courts and who are unable to effectively communicate in English blood Aboriginals, and the number of such cases in any year would be relatively low in comparison to the number of cases dealt with by the courts. Northern Territory: Legal Aid (Question No. 997>

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: the Minister for the Interior, upon notice: How many indigent defendants in the lower courts of the Northern Territory in each of the last 5 years (a) were granted, (b) and (c) did not request free legal representation? Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: No record is kept of the numbers of persons seek free legal representation of the Territory and it is therefore not possible to say how many indigent defendants were denied, or did not seek, free legal representation. Social Welfare Ordinance of the Territory, the Director of Social Welfare has authority to pay fees for legal assistance to persons who, in the opinion of the Director, are socially or economically in need of assistance. This authority is delegated to District Welfare Officers throughout the Terrirehabilitation tory and no separate records are kept of assistance given. Northern Territory: Mental Defectives (Question No. 998)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: the Minister for the and (c) Interior, upon notice: 1. How many residents of the Northern Terriin each of the last 5 years have been convicted under the Mental Defectives Ordinance? 2. In which institutions have such residents been of Aboriginal descent. confined? Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: 1. 1963-64, 14; 1964-65, 21; 1965-66, 8; 1966-67. Aboriginals 11; 1967-68, 8. 2. All patients have been placed in mental in South Australia at the discretion of the South Australian Hospitals Department. Usually patients are taken to the Enfield Receiving Hospital and later moved to Hillcrest Hospital. Northern Territory: Juvenile Offenders (Question No. 999)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: the Minister for the Interior, upon notice: 1. How many juvenile offenders were confined at Fannie Bay gaol in each of the last 5 2. What facilities for rehabilitation training are provided at the gaol? Mr Nixon-The answer to the honourable are fullmember's question is as follows: 1. 1963-64, 11; 1964-65, 27; 1965-66, 17; 1966-67, 10; 1967-68, 17. 2. No training is given within the gaol. Juvenile prisoners receive training at the Adult Education Centre in academic subjects and in practical subjects such as art, pottery and woodwork. Northern Territory: Delinquent Girls (Question No. 1000)

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: the Minister for the were denied Interior, upon notice: 1. What facilities for the detention of delinquent girls are available in the Northern Territory? 2. How many delinquent girls have been sent for detention outside the Territory in each of the who last 5 years, and in what institutions were they in the lower courts detained? Mr Nixon-The answers to the honourUnder the able member's questions are as follows: 1. There are no special facilities at present for the detention of delinquent girls in the Northern Territory. A new training and assessment centre will however open in the near future and this will provide security accommodation for girls with training to be provided by a skilled staff including psychologists, social workers and group workers. 2. No girls have been sent outside the Territory for the purpose of detention during the past S years. Twenty-two girls have been transferred outside the Territory for training in institutions where there is some degree of security, tions operated by the Sisters of the Good Shepherd in Adelaide, Melbourne and Brisbane. It is emphasised however that these girls were transferred for training and not for detention purposes. Civil Aviation (Question No. 1021) Mr Collard asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: 1. Did he or his Department recommend or make the request that MACRobertson Miller Airlines Ltd drop out of uneconomical air service routes in Western Australia in favour of commuter air services? 2. If so, for what reason other than to reduce subsidy pay but was the request made'? 3. Did he expect a substantial increase in the costs of travel and cargo delivery as. the result of the changeover? 4. Was any consideration given to subsidising the commuter airlines to keep costs of travel and cargo delivery to a reasonable level? 5. Is it claimed that the charges now being made are reasonable?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1 and 2. MACRobertson Miller Airlines Ltd and the Commonwealth are concerned at the trend towards increasing subsidy need with an estimated requirement of more than $400;000 for the current year. The Company submitted proposals to withconsideration. draw from the more uneconomical routes in favour of commuter air services. 3. It was anticipated that the consumer would be required to bear a higher proportion of the costs involved though the extent of any increase was not expected to be steep. 4. The Government recently reviewed its policy on subsidising air services and decided that sideration will be given to subsidising operators who take over existing subsidised developmental airline services provided a saving in subsidy will be achieved. 5. In the light of costs of operation, the type of aircraft being used and the frequency of service provided it is considered that the present charges are reasonable. Civil Aviation (Question No. 1022) Mr Collard asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: 1. Which companies (a) have taken over, or (b) are expected to take over the airline services which MACRobertson-Miller Airlines Ltd now operate or will, in the near future, cease to operate? 2. Has he approved the charges for air fares and freights to be made or now being made for the new services in each instance? 3. If not, on which specific routes have charges principally institubeen approved? 4. Have any of the new companies applied for subsidies? If so, have they been approved? 5. Where no application for subsidy has been made could a successful application at this stage be the means of reducing current fares and freight charges or would the subsidy only be granted to prevent any further increases in charges?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as foUows: 1. Port Hedland stations services-Murchiso n Airlines Pty Ltd Carnarvon to Shark Bay, Carnarvon to Gascoyne Junction-Murchiso n Airlines Pty Ltd Perth-Geraldton to the Murchison area-Hick s Airlines Pty Ltd Perth-Rottnest Island-Murchiso n Airlines Pty Ltd, Civil Flying Services (WA.) Pty Ltd Perth-Albany-Civi l Flying Services (WA.) Pty Ltd Kalgoorlie-Norseman-Esperance, Kalgoorlie-Leonora-Laverton-Noesk a Aviation. 2 and 3. I have approved fares and freight rates on the following services: Port Hedland stations Perth-Geraldton to the MuTchison area Perth-Rottnest Island Perth-Albany Kalgoorlie-Norseman-Esperance Kalgoorlie-Leonora-Laverton. The fares and freight rates from Carnarvon "to Shark Bay and Gascoyne Junction are still under 4. None of the new companies has applied for subsidy. 5. This would depend on the detailed investigation which will be made of the applications for Commonwealth air service subsidy. Whilst not wishing to anticipate the results of any such investigations it would seem more likely that the consubsidy would be granted to prevent any further commuter increases in charges. Civil Aviation (Question No. 1023) Mr Collard asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: 1. Has there been a recent steep increase in air fare and freight charges to northern areas of Western Australia? 2. Is it a fact that from Perth to (a) Shark Bay, (b) Gascoyne Junction and (c) Marble Bar air fares have increased from(i) $21.80 to $51.40 (ii) $39.90 to $49.00 and (iii) $56.80 to $72.00 respectively, and freight charges have increased from; (a) 13 to 27 cents per lb (b) 16 to 27 cents per lb and (c) 22 to 36 cents per Ib respectively? 3. If so, did he approve these charges? 4. Are the airline companies operating on these routes(a) tn receipt of subsidy, or (b) entitled to subsidy if their profits are below a certain figure? 5. Will the recent increases in charges substantially reduce the need for subsidy? Mr Swam-The following furnished: 1. There have been increases in fare and freight rates to these areas. 2. Apart from two minor differences, the fares and freight rates are as set out in the question. 3. Those to Marble Bar have been approved but those to Shark Bay and Gascoyne Junction or, more correctly, from Carnarvon to Shark Bay and Gascoyne Junction are still under consideration. It must be appreciated that changes in the route structure were involved and indirect routings to these centres are now necessary. 4. (a) No subsidies have been sought by the commuter operators serving these routes, (b) This could only be determined by the detailed investigaable tion of the financial affairs of the companies which would follow any request they might make for Commonwealth air service subsidy. 5. A substantial reduction in subsidy should result from these increases. (Question No. 1050) Mr Charies Jones asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: 1. Are some of the companies which operate commuter air services linking country centres allocating to passengers the co-pilot's seat with live controls? 2. If so, is this a safe procedure?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: PERSONS WATTING
text: Th c answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1. In some cases passengers are carried in commuter service aircraft in seats in which dual controls are fined. The Air Navigation Orders require that when passengers occupy such seats, specific precautions must be taken to ensure that the controls are not interfered with during flight. 2. This procedure is quite safe provided the precautions prescribed in the Air Navigation Orders are complied with. Postmaster-General's Department (Question No. 941) Dr Everingham asked the Postmaster General, upon notice: 1. Has his attention been drawn to a report entitled 'Divergence in Departmental Policy' in the Medical Journal of Australia of 19th October, at page 698? 2. Will he seek specialised advice to confirm or refute the statements of Dr T. H. Crouch that (a) the Minister's Department demoted and demoralised a fifty-year-old man due to a coronary reply is episode, (b) the patient is fitter than before the attack due to treatment and self-discipline and (c) such departmental action contradicts rehabilitation principles laid down by the Department of Health? 3. If leading specialists decide the man's new and menial manual work is better for his happiness and coronary arteries and for the public's safety than his former supervisory work, which is alleged to have required him to drive a car more, will the Minister consider the need for specialised rehabilitation to help convey such an optimistic viewpoint to demoralised demotees? Mr Huline-The answers to the honour member's questions are as follows: 1. A copy of the report entitled 'Divergence in Departmental Policy' in the Medical Journal of Australia, dated 19th October 1968, at page 698, has been perused. 2. (a) The Department has not demoted the Civil Aviation officer concerned, as he has been placed in his former position, although on restricted duties, (b) The officer has been medically examined by the Commonwealth Medical Officer on five occasions since he resumed duty early this year following his coronary episode. After each examination the Commonwealth Medical Officer bas stipulated restricted duties, and on the last occasion it was expressly specified that he was fit for light duty not above ground or floor level, was not to drive a vehicle, and was not to lift anything above 40 Ih in weight or work near moving machinery, (c) In accordance with the relevant provisions pursuant to the Public Service Act, all Commonwealth Departments are obliged to abide by the certifications of Commonwealth Medical Officers, whose prerogative it is to decide whether specialist opinion is necessary or desirable. 3. The Department's Welfare Section is available to help staff placed on light duties, either permanently or temporarily, to obtain suitable placement in accordance with the medical restrictions imposed. It has been ascertained that this assistance was given to the particular oflicer concerned, both during his absence on sick leave and after his return to work.

Civil Aviation (Question No. 1051) Mr Charles Jones asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: 1. What are the names of the companies operating commuter air servioes Unking couutry centres in each State of the Commonwealth? 2. What types of aircraft are used on these services and what is the age of each aircraft? 3. Is each aircraft fitted with weather radar? If not, why not?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: S S S S S S S S
text: The answers are as follows: Hereunder is a statement listing within each State the various commuter operators together with the types of aircraft, registration marking and date of manufacture of each. None of these aircraft is fitted or required to be fitted with weather radar as it is required to be fitted only in the following types of aircraft: Operator Masling Aviation Engineering Ltd .. Davey Air Services Pty Ltd Lindeman Aerial Services Pty Ltd Western Air Navigation Ltd C. W. Lanham trading as Lanham's Air Taxi Service (a) Turbine powered aircraft having a maximum permissible take-off weight in excess of 50,000 lb; (b) turbine powered aircraft having a maximum permissible take-off weight in excess of 12,500 lb which are engaged in regular public transport or charter operations; (c) pressurised piston engined aircraft having a maximum permissible take-oft weight in excess of 50,000 lb; and (d) DC4 type aircraft and variations of this type engaged in regular public transport and charter operations. These requirements were developed having regard for the normal operating speeds of the aircraft concerned and the altitude at which they normally would fly. There are also economic and practical difficulties involved in the fitment of weather radar to aircraft of the type used in commuter services, ail of which bave a maximum take-off weight of less than 12,500 lb. Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Title: TASMANIA
text: the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice: 1. Did the Governor General on 12th March 1968 announce that the Government would introduce legislation for the reconstruction of the dairying industry? 2. Did the Prime Minister on 30th September 1968 write to the Premiers with proposals for such reconstruction? 3. Did he on 21st November 1968 tell me that the Prime Minister had been unable to put the proposals to the Premiers until there was a degree of uniformity between the State laws? 4. What changes were made in the relevant laws of the several States between the Governor General's speech and the Prime Minister's letter?

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Title: TASMANIA
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1. Yes. 2. Yes. 3 and 4. On 21st November 1968 I indicated that negotiations had been taking place in an effort to find a basis for an offer to the States that account of the varying laws relating to land and land tenure in the different States. The efforts of the officers were sufficiently encouraging to enable the Commonwealth to put a common offer States on 30th September as indicated above. Civil Aviation (Question No. 1070) Mr Charles Jones asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice: What is the cost of aviation fuel and what proportion of the cost is tax in (a) Australia, (b) the United States, (c) the United Kingdom, (d) France, (e) Japan, CO Italy, (g) India, (h) West Germany?

Speaker: Mr SWARTZ
Title: TASMANIA
text: The following furnished: A precise answer to the question is not possible, because prices of fuels vary considerably within countries. The table below therefore specifies the posted prices of aviation turbine fuel at particular airports. It is to be emphasised that these are the maximum prices at those airports, and the airlines will, in general, pay lower prices under their confidential contracts with suppliers. Because of the special arrangements in the United States, posted airport prices for fuel are not published. Taxes also vary from state to state. In view of this complication, Canada (Vancouver) has been substituted in the table. Dairying CENTS PER IMPERIAL GALLON (APPROX.) text: the Treasurer, upon notice: 1. What is the last year for which the Statistician can providefiguresof (a) the number and (b) the percentage of (i) premises and (ii) residents served by sewerage in each capital? 2. What were thefiguresfor (a) that year, (b) took 10 years earlier and (c) 20 years earlier?

Speaker: Mr MCMAHON
Title: TASMANIA
text: The answer to the to the honourable member's questions is as follows: Further to my interim reply which appeared in Hansard of 27th November 1968, the Commonwealth Statistician has now furnished the following advice. The year ended June 1967 is the latest year for which information relating to sewerage services is available. However, as definitive information relating to total population in the area served by the sewerage authority in each State capital is in general available only for census years, be has supplied figures for the census years 1947, 1954 and 1966 in place of the years requested by the honourable member. He also states that the various authorities use varying concepts for measuring reply is connections or services and it is not possible to determine the percentage of premises served in each State capital. The available information which appears most pertinent to the honourable member's question is set out in the tablesbelow. This relates to the areas served by the authoriues providing sewerage services to the whole or a major part of the metropolitan area in each State. These areas do not correspond to the metropolitan area for statistical purposes and, in the case of New South Wales, include important urban areas outside the Sydney metropolitan area. The figures for 'properties served', 'premises connected', etc., and 'estimated population served' were obtained from the authorities concerned for all States except Western Australia. For Western Australia the Metropolitan Sewerage and Drainage Board provided the figures for 'No. of services' and the 'Estimated population in sewered area' was compiled, from census returns. The figures for 'Total population in area served' have been compiled from census returns and relate as nearly as practicable to the areas served by the respective authorities at successive census dates. It should be noted that the areas served have changed over the period. These boundary changes affect the percentages of population served and the figures given in the final columns of the table accordingly do not seem particularly meaningful. Does any school system in Australia provide an examination which qualifies for matriculation in every university and college of advanaed education in Australia? 2. What are the matriculation requirements for the principal faculties in each university and college of advanced education? 3. What steps have been taken to co-ordinate or standardise matriculation requirements throughout Australia?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: QUEENSLAND
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as examination. follows: REVENUE , DEBT CHARGES AND PERCENTAGE OF NA New Queens- South Western TasSouth Victoria land Australia Australia mania Total Wales 1949-50 37.820 n.a. 19.194 5,810 5,813 2,536 n.a. 8,203 n.a. 6,093 378 527 601 n.a. 21.69 n.a. 31.74 6.SI 9.07 23.70 n.a. 1954-55 89,732 39,546 34.140 13,166 12,042 5,096 193,722 15,802 3,950 10,156 1,022 1,228 1,094 33,252 17.61 9.99 29.75 7.76 10.20 21.47 17.16 1959-60 147,560 68,452 59,264 21.368 19,176 8.082 323.902 28,978 7,680 18506 : 1,684 2,974 2,098 61,920 19.64 11.22 31.23 7.88 15.51 25.96 19.12 1964-65 236,549 103,782 83.447 32,383 35,723 13,618 505,503 48,713 14,486 30,233 3,652 5,428 4,396 106,908 20.59 13.96 36.23 11.28 15.19 32.28 21.15 (b) Consists of revenue for ordinary services plus the surplus or is receipts less operating expenditure before charging for payments, exchange on interest payments and redemptions. 1. The educational systems in the various States are quite independent of one another, and the final secondary school examination is in each case used as an entrance examination to the university or universities in that State, lt is true, however, that universities in other States may admit 'ad ettndem statum' those students eligible for admittance to any 'recognised' university. There is no standard examination for entry to every College of Advanced Education. Each college has its own entry requirements based on the secondary school system in each State. Qualifications of students from overseas or interstate are assessed for equivalence by individual colleges for acceptance into particular courses of study. 2. Matriculation to ail universities depends on results obtained in the final secondary school The main requirements are set out in the following table. TasmaniaTasmania, University of: 1968 1969 .. 0)5 (a) At Macquarie University there is no prescribed number a pass is not compulsory. (b) Entrance to the University of Sydney may also be obtained held in February. (cl From 1969, papers in the Western Australian Leaving matriculation: a pass in five subjects including three In addition to the requirements shown, some universities require passes in certain subjects for entry into particular faculties or courses. Although a student may he eligible for admittance to a university, he may not be eligible for entry to certain faculties, where various studies are a pre-requisite. A list of pre-requisites for all Australian universities is set out below. Minimum Compulsory Minimum standards Aggregate of marks of passes subjects Three of the subjects must English Minimum aggregate of be at level 2 marks determined by the professorial board (a) Minimum aggregate of marks determined by the Council in English and four other subjects Three of the subjects must English Minimum aggregate of be at level 2 marks determined by the University Three of the subjects must English be at level 2 Three subjects must be English Minimum aggregate of passed at level 2 marks determined by the professorial board Four subjects must be English passed at level 2 English Expression All of the subjects roust English Total score of 22 or above be at grade 4 or higher All of the subjects must English be at grade D or higher English Three of the subjects must English passed at matriculation level(c) 5 Three of the subjects must be at advanced level Three of the subjects must be at advanced level or (ii)4 All subjects must be at advanced level of passes. Marks obtained in English must be counted though, at that University's matriculation examination, normally Certificate Examination will be set at two levels, leaving and at matriculation level wiil be required for matriculation. Entrance to diploma courses at College of Advanced Education is generally by a pass in the final secondary schools examination including pre-requisite subjects for some courses. However, there are cases, notably in Victoria, where entry to some diploma courses is at a level one year below completion of secondary schooling (i.e. Victorian Leaving Certificate). In such cases the first year of the course is regarded as advancing the student to full secondary schooling level. Detailed entry requirements for diploma courses at Colleges of Advanced Education are readily available in the college handbooks. However, 1I have listed below the entry requirements for some diploma courses in some of the main colleges. 3. Both South Australian universities have agreed on common matriculation requirements, and so too have the three universities in Victoria. The Australian Nauonal University (in the Australian Capital Territory), and the Universities of Newcastle and of New South Wales (both in New South Wales), have agreed on common matriculation requirements. The other universities in New South Wales have their own matriculation requirements. With respect to entry standards for colleges of advanced education, see answer to question 1. Title: DEBT CHARGES TO REVENUE

However, Uie following information, which it must be stressed is incomplete and may well contain inaccuracies, may be of use. Some seventy Australian secondary schools, both government and private, currently offer courses in at least one modern Asian language. The total number of students involved is approximately 3,500. The majority are studying Indonesian and Japanese, with a small minority undertaking studies in Chinese. The latest information available to my Department is given in the following Table No. 1, At the tertiary level, the situation in 1968 was that courses in Japanese and Indonesian or Malay were available at four universities and Chinese at three. Information for individual universities is given in the following Table No. 2. Northern Temtory: Tertiary Education (Question No. 860) Mr Whitlam asked the Minister for Education and Science, upon notice: 1. What was the date and what were the terms of the notification by the University of Queensland that it would lake no more external students from the Northern Territory? 2. What opportunities for tertiary education have now been arranged for residents of the Northern Territory?

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Title: ASIAN LANGUAGES AVAILABLE AT
text: The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: 1. On 10th November 1966 the University of Queensland notified the Commonwealth Government that the University Senate had decided no further enrolments from external students in the Northern Territory would be accepted after (he 1967 academic year. The University stated that existing money and staff were heavily pressed and it was forced to restrict enrolments from both Queensland and elsewhere. Talks were held between the Commonwealth Department of Territories and the University of Queensland in which the importance of the existing service was pointed out, there being sixty-six students enrolled at the time. As a result of these discussions the Vice-Chancellor of the University, Sir Fred Schoncll, recommended to the University Senate that enrolment of Northern Territory students be continued for a further three years. On Sth October 1967 the Senate approved that the present service to external students from the Northern Territory be continued for the years 1968, 1969 and 1970. The Commonwealth agreed to make a grant of $5,000 per annum for the three; years towards the cost of the service. Sanskrit 2. In addition to courses of the University of Japanese Queensland, other facilities are available. These are Chinese frequently provided in co-operation with the Javanese Northern Territory Adult Education Centre in Darwin which is conducted for the Department Chinese of Education and Science by the South Australian Bengali Education Department. Japanese (a) Students from the University of Western Australia who have completed at least five units may continue their courses externally. (b) The Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology and the Western Australian Institute of Technology both provide external courses for students in the Northern Territory. Indonesian and Malay Tutorials are given at the Adult Education Chinese Centre. (c) The University of Adelaide grants exemption from lectures in certain cases, particularly teachers, so enabling Northern Territory students to study at this institution. (d) Students may also obtain correspondence courses in some subjects from the Technical Correspondence College, Adelaide, and attend tutorials at the Adult Education Centre. (e) Northern Territory teachers may study soma subjects externally from teachers' colleges in South Australia. Again tutorials are provided by the Adult Education Centre. (f) The Adult Education Centre acts as agent for the University of London for residents of the Northern Territory enrolled as external students of that institution. Students from the Northern Territory who wish to undertake either full-time or part-time tertiary education can compete for Commonwealth University or Advanced Education Scholarships. In addition, as from the beginning of 1969, a new scholarship scheme will provide 25 tertiary level ' scholarships each year for students whose parents are permanent residents of the Northern Territory. They will be awarded on a competitive basis to students who do not receive the offer of a Commonwealth University or Advanced Education Scholarship. The awards will cover the cost of tuition and certain other compulsory fees and will be tenable in any approved tertiary level course. Northern Territory students doing approved tertiary courses may also be assisted with the cost of their fares betweeu their home in the Northern Territory and the institution they attend. I have asked the Australian Universities Commission to examine the general question of facilities for external students in all States because both the Commonwealth Government and the Universities Commission are conscious of the importance of external studies for the improvement of qualifications particularly for country students.
